page.title: 01INTRODUCTION
page.content: The great survey of 1087, now known as the{Domesday Book,}described an England of two peoples, a dominant Norman aristocracy and the native English. This contrast is reflected in {Blantyre High's}contribution to the Domsday Project nine centuries later. We examine{ Blantyre}and{Bothwell} villages separated only by the the River Clyde, yet very different. {Bothwell}is a conservation area, sought after by the house - buyer, while{Blantyre}is an area of deprivation with high unemployment; Bothwells history features the aristocratic Earls,whle Blantyre's fame rest on the working class figure of Dr. Livinstone. {Domesday Book}was sometimes used as legal evidence; our work may not prove as definitive, but has much to offer to those interested inthe two villages
